newsitem.title: FRANCE: French stocks end touch lower on profit-taking.
newsitem.headline: French stocks end touch lower on profit-taking.

text.p: French shares closed on Friday with a slight loss as investors took profits ahead of the weekend.

Traders said the market needed a breather after storming to fresh highs during the week, helped by company 1996 turnover figures which were broadly welcomed, a storming Wall Street and rising dolllar.
The CAC-40 index closed down 0.99 point or 0.04 percent at 2,627.42 and was up 1.1 percent on the week. The CAC-40 futures contract was down 3.5 at 2,631 from Thursday's close.
Volume was a hefty 8.87 billion francs.
Pierre Vignaud, technical analyst at EIFB, believes the CAC-40 will face difficulty in breaking through resistance between 2,635 and 2,670 and could consolidate down to 2,540.
Alcatel Alsthom was the most active stock, and rose 2.44 percent to 587 francs with 997,000 shares traded, after retreating 2.05 percent on Thursday.
Cie Generale des Eaux retreated 1.25 percent to 792 francs with 603,711 shares changing hands, with some profit-taking after recent rises.

Carrefour rose 3.97 percent to 3,558 francs, with 113,000 shares traded. The stock, which underperformed in the January rise that took the market to new highs, hit its record high of 3,569 in the session.
Rhone-Poulenc gained 3.59 percent to 193.33 francs, with 1.9 million shares changing hands, benefiting from a lunchtime presentation managing director Igor Landau organised by Exane.
PSA dropped 4.58 percent to 584 francs, partly on the back of an an article in La Vie Francaise speculating its losses could run between 2.5 billion to three billion francs.
